 STAFF APPRAISAL REPORT BRAZIL RIO DE JANEIRO STATE REFORM--PRIVATIZATION LOAN 1. COUNTRY AND STATE BACKGROUND Country Context 1.1 Brazil's public sector is highly decentralized. Its government is comprised of the federal government, 26 state governments, a federal district, and approximately 5,500 local governments or municipalities. Democratization and constitutional revisions in the 1980s increased the degree of resources under sub-national control, and the degree of local political autonomy in their allocation. Approximately half of budgetary public expenditures are now made by sub-national governments. 1.2 The performance of state and local governments is a source of concern for both macro- and microeconomic reasons. The macroeconomic concern arises from state fiscal behavior. Despite their fundamental importance to macroeconomic policy formulation and implementation, state governments operate semi-independently of the federal government, driven by their own tax bases, formula-driven transfers and borrowing. Periodic state fiscal crises have prompted bailouts or emergency loans from the federal government. The indebtedness of the Brazilian states has now reached crisis proportions, posing a serious threat to macroeconomic stability. In addition, losses at state-owned banks pose a threat to the stability of the financial system. 1.3 From a microeconomic perspective, the concern is with the cost and quality of services provided by subnational governments. Key infrastructure services, including power, gas, water supply and sanitation, as well as urban transport, are now provided by state-run monopolies. Due to overstaffing, weak management and lack of investment, the coverage and reliability of these services lags behind consumer demand. Subsidies to loss- making enterprises divert funding from key state social services: education, health, and public security.
 2 Recent Country Economic Policies and Developments 1.4 The most prominent feature of Brazil's recent economic history has been chronic and rising inflation. Monthly inflation peaks of 80 percent and 50 percent were reached in 1990 and 1994, respectively. Large fiscal and quasi-fiscal deficits and an over-extended public sector were major factors underlying this phenomenon. Inflation at these levels slowed growth and investment, distorted the pattern of economic activities and exacerbated the maldistribution of income. Successive stabilization plans were introduced in the 1980s--most of them with price and wage freeze components--but these were successful in containing prices only for very limited periods. 1.5 In mid- 1994, as the Minister of Finance in the prior (Itamar Franco) administration, President Fernando Henrique Cardoso introduced the Real stabilization plan. This plan included an initial fiscal and wage adjustment, an exchange rate anchor (modified later in 1995, and made less rigid) and tight monetary policy. The plan has had remarkable success. Annual inflation fell from 929 percent in 1994 to 22 percent in 1995 and to nine percent in 1996. Inflation in the first two months of 1997 averaged six percent in annualized terms.The balance of payments also remains manageable. Gross international reserves stand at US$59 billion (as of January 1997) or nine months of imports of goods and factor services. This has occurred despite a weakening of the current account deficit to 3.3 percent of GDP (fourth quarter, 1996). These positive outcomes for inflation and the balance of payments appear set to continue in the medium term. 1.6 The Real stabilization plan had a major and somewhat unexpected impact on state finances, and, consequently, on the consolidated finances of the government. A tightening of monetary policy as part of the plan caused average annual real overnight interest rates to rise to 25 percent in 1995, before falling to 18 percent in 1996. As much of state debt was either financed on variable terms (the interest rate on state bonds, for example, was tied to the federal bond rate) or indexed to interest-rate-sensitive indicators, states experienced rising costs of debt service and large increases in the size of outstanding principal. State government debt now totals over US$120 billion (excluding arrears). Ninety-eight percent of this is owed to federal government and its agents-the Central Bank, Caixa Econ6mica Federal, and the Banco do Brasil. 1.7 The Real Plan also removed a past mechanism of state internal financial control: the ability to reduce real salaries and pensions via inflation. As a result, state governments have found themselves paying unusually high salaries in real terms. By 1996, many states were undergoing fiscal crises. Even when they deferred paying much of their debt and began cutting capital outlays drastically, they still had insufficient funds to pay wages. Note: "-" indicates surplus. 1.8 In the long run, continuing high fiscal deficits financed by debt are incompatible with stabilization. As a result, there is pressure to adjust. Since Brazil is fiscally decentralized and the deficits are greater at the state level, adjustment is required at the state, as well as the federal, level. 1.9 Efforts to induce adjustment at the state level have not been wholly successful, however. Constitutional amendments that would allow the state (and federal) governments to dismiss excess staff and reduce pension benefits were defeated in the 1996 session of Congress. More recent efforts to place the states on a sound financial footing through comprehensive debt workouts have not lived up to expectations. The federal government has now signed comprehensive debt agreements with the four largest debtor states: Sao Paulo, Rio de Janeiro, Minas Gerais and Rio Grande do Sul. In all four states, the outstanding stock of state bonds is to be refinanced, at six percent real interest, for 30 years. The interest rate in Rio de Janeiro will depend on the ultimate valuation of the assets transferred by the state to the federal government. If the state assets are equal to ten percent of the value of the refinanced debt, the interest rate will be 7.5 percent. For each additional one percentage point of debt coverage, the interest rate will be reduced by 0.15 down to a minimum interest rate of 6 percent. In addition, in Sao Paulo and Rio de Janeiro, debts to state banks and certain liabilities arising from the states' ownership of their banks have also been included in the financing package. As the agreements permit states to capitalize debt service in excess of 13 percent of revenues, the total stock of state debt will likely grow over the next several years, rather than decline.
 4 Bank Strategy 1.10 The Rio de Janeiro SRPL is one of four state reform projects planned for Brazil. As initially conceived, these projects had two objectives: immediate fiscal adjustment and longer term structural reform. A crucial element of fiscal adjustment was to be a workout of the debt owed by the states to the federal government. It was expected that this workout, combined with tax increases, payroll cuts, and curbs on investment at the state level, would reduce the states' debt service to an affordable level within two to three years. As noted above, the debt agreements are unlikely to achieve this target. 1.11 In response, the projects have been restructured. They now consist in carrying out specific actions linked to the project objective of improving both service delivery through privatization and the state's fiscal condition. Each project will include a public expenditure review requirement in the policy matrix, whose details will be spelled out in a letter of development policy. The first example was the Rio Grande do Sul State Reform Loan approved by the Board of Executive Directors on March 4, 1997 (Report No. P- 6982-BR). 1.12 However, since the state of Rio de Janeiro was particularly affected by its debt workout, the project has been further restructured to focus solely on the structural objective--the privatization or concession of state enterprises. Although its existing debts were rescheduled, the state was required to assume Rs.$6.3 billion in the liabilities of its state bank. This doubled the state's stock of debt, and rendered the prospect of fiscal recovery more remote. As a result, Rio de Janeiro is a particularly clear example of the change in SRL project objectives. While the state's return to creditworthiness is fairly distant, its privatization program is particularly comprehensive and well-advanced. Privatization of its state bank, a source of quasi-fiscal losses in the past, is especially important.
 5 2. THE STATE PRIVATIZATION PROGRAM 2.1 Background. The state of Rio de Janeiro is located on the south-east coast of Brazil, adjacent to the states of Sao Paulo, Minas Gerais and Espirito Santo. The state is the third largest in terms of population (13.2 million) and tied for second (with Minas Gerais) in terms of economic size. The population is urbanized, with over 95 percent living in urban areas. The city of Rio de Janeiro is the second largest population center in Brazil. 2.2 The city of Rio enjoys a special position in the Brazilian national context. It was the national capital from the late eighteenth century until the inauguration of Brasilia in 1960. Its growth coincided with the movement of the Portuguese royal court to the city in 1808, and it enjoyed the status of being the cultural, journalistic, intellectual and financial center of Brazil for many years, until eclipsed in the second half of this century by Sao Paulo. In 1974, the state of Guanabara was merged with the former state of Rio de Janeiro to become the new state of Rio de Janeiro, whose capital is Rio. 2.3 This transfer left the city with an overdimensioned work force at a time of growing immigration. Slums (favelas) have grown along with more prosperous areas. The tourist trade has suffered as crime and violence in the city rose, partly linked to a large illegal trade in drugs. With the international environment conference in 1992 and the improvement in the crime situation due to firmer security action since 1994, Rio is slowly recovering its reputation as an attractive, cosmopolitan city. Given the strong association abroad between Rio and Brazil's image, there are probably considerable externalities in a recovery of Rio de Janeiro. 2.4 Program Setting. The present administration, which took office on January 1, 1995, inherited a difficult financial situation, with large commitments to personnel, a heavy debt burden and a major loss-making bank. The state's overextended civil service consumed 84 percent of state revenues in 1995. State debt, excluding the liabilities of the state bank, totaled Rs.$7.3 billion, equal to 1.4 times state revenues (all values are expressed in prices of December 1996). Of this, 70 percent consisted of high-cost state bonds, which bore a real annual interest rate of 33 percent in 1995. The administration responded by freezing hiring, cutting investments and taking advantage of the federal government's willingness to permit interest on state bonds to be capitalized. As a result, in 1996, the state was successful in holding personnel costs to their 1995 level (as a percent of revenues) and maintaining investment spending at a minimal seven percent of revenues. The state's debt stock, however, continued to grow. Due to the capitalization of unpaid interest on state bonds, new borrowing to finance arrears to personnel, and
 6 growth in the stock of arrears themselves, the state's total stock of debt increased to Rs.$8.3 billion by the end of 1996. 2.5 The state's recent debt agreement with the federal government (whose protocol was initialed in January 1997) particularly affected its stock of debt and its prospects in fiscal improvement. Under the agreement, the state's bond debt, along with certain other existing contractual debts, will be transformed into a 30 year debt to the federal treasury. As part of the agreement, however, the state is required to acknowledge Rs. $6.3 billion in liabilities arising from its ownership of the state bank Banco do Estado do Rio de Janeiro (BANERJ). This will be included in the package of refinanced debt, and will roughly double the amount of outstanding state contractual and bonded debt. Under the agreement, the state is required to make an upfront transfer of assets to the federal government, which will be partly used to reduce the initial stock of debt. The state estimates the value of assets to be transferred (net of the amount the state can use to service debt) at Rs. $2.0 billion. Even if this valuation prevails, the state's total debt will grow to Rs.$13 billion. 2.6 The interest rate on the refinanced debt will range from six percent to 7.5 percent depending on the ultimate valuation of the assets transferred by the state. Even at 7.5 percent, this represents a substantial drop in the state's average cost of funds. In terms of its impact on debt service, however, it is not large enough to offset the growth in the stock of debt due to the incorporation of BANERJ liabilities. 2.7 Debt service on the refinanced debt, along with debt service from earlier reschedulings, will be subject to a debt service cap of 13 percent of net recurrent revenues. Due to transitional clauses in the debt agreement, the effective debt ceiling in 1997 will be about ten percent of revenues, rising to 11.5 percent of revenues in 1998. The stock of debt is therefore expected to grow, due to the capitalization of debt service above the 13 percent ceiling. At the same time, arrears are expected to increase. Even with the 13 percent ceiling, the state will be required to increase its cash outlays for debt service. Given the rigidity of its other spending obligations, the state is likely to finance this through increased arrears. 2.8 In contrast to its difficulties in fiscal adjustment, the state has successfully pursued an extremely ambitious program of structural reform. Under the program, the state has already sold the state electricity company, Companhia de Electricidade do Estado do Rio de Janeiro (CERJ) and its state bank, Banco do Estado do Rio de Janeiro (BANERJ). Liquidation of the bad part of the state bank is now under way. It will sell the state gas distribution company, Companhia Estadual do Gas (CEG), in 1997. It will also concession the state suburban railway company (Flumitrens) and subway system (Metro), as well as major elements of the state water and sanitation company, Companhia Estadual de Agua e Esgoto (CEDAE) in early 1998. While aimed partly at the fiscal crisis, these measures are primarily intended to improve the efficiency of infrastructure services in the state, and end the state's fiscal exposure to BANERJ's losses. As a group, these measures constitute the most ambitious and most advanced state privatization program in Brazil.
 7 2.9 Major Components. The state privatization program which is detailed in Governor Alencar' s State Privatization Program Letter (Annex A) includes two components: A. Privatization/Liquidation of the State Bank (BANERJ) B. Privatization or Concession of Public Enterprises A. PRIVATIZATION/LIQUIDATION OF STATE BANK (BANERJ) Overview 2.10 Background. The present Banco do Estado do Rio de Janeiro (BANERJ) was created in November 1976, by merging the Banco do Estado da Guanabara (BEG) with the previous Banco do Estado do Rio de Janeiro. Currently, BANERJ's issued share capital is Rs.$158 million--57.3 percent in voting shares and 42.7 percent in non-voting preferred shares. The main shareholders are the state of Rio de Janeiro--with 80.3 percent of the voting shares and 68.7 percent of the preferred shares, and the bank's pension fund (PREVI-BANERJ)--with 13 percent of the voting shares and 26.8 percent of the preferred shares. The remaining capital is in the hands of many small private shareholders (6.7 percent of total capital). BANERJ's shares are formally quoted on the Rio stock exchange, but trading activity is limited. At the end of 1995, BANERJ had 11,500 employees in a network of 19 regional offices supervising 218 branches, to which reported 104 sub-branches and 322 other sales outlets. The bank' s network essentially covers the states of Rio de Janeiro, Minas Gerais and Sao Paulo. BANERJ has a network of 70 branches (the largest of any bank ) in the city of Rio de Janeiro alone. 2.11 The bank, which had been in a weak financial condition since the early 1990s, began incurring substantial operating losses after the introduction of the Real plan in 1994. The bank' s net worth declined from Rs.$124 million at the end of 1993, to a negative Rs.$1.03 billion at the end of 1994. To remedy the situation, the incoming Alencar government requested the central bank to maintain BANERJ under a special temporary administration regime during the whole year of 1995. However, the bank's financial condition continued to deteriorate. By mid-1995, its net worth had exceeded a negative Rs.$1.35 billion. To prevent further deterioration, in October 1995, the Alencar government and the central bank mutually agreed to look for a private bank to manage BANERJ and prepare it for privatization (or liquidation). The tender for the management and privatization contract was won by the private investment bank Banco Bozano Simonsen (BBS) in December 1995. Reform Strategy 2.12 Acting on the recommendation of BBS, the state decided to privatize BANERJ. To prepare it for sale, the state divided the bank's existing assets and liabilities, transferring about 70 percent of the liabilities and about 35 percent of the assets to the state treasury. As shown in Table 2.1, the transferred liabilities consisted of liabilities to

Under the terms of the debt agreement, the federal government agreed to refinance this debt, at between six percent and 7.5 percent real interest for 30 years, subject to the overall debt ceiling of 13 percent. The assets transferred total Rs.$1.7 billion, and include the bank's bond portfolio, its claims against the federal government, and the state's own contractual debt to BANERJ. The state intends to use these assets, plus the proceeds from the sale of the BANERJ itself, to satisfy the asset-transfer requirements of its debt agreement with the federal government. PRIVATIZATION OR CONCESSION OF PUBLIC ENTERPRISES 2.14 Starting in early 1995, the government has been radically redefining the role of the state in the provision of urban transport and utility services, relying increasingly on private firms to provide such services. When Governor Alencar presented his privatization, concession and new regulatory program to the Rio State Assembly in November 1995, more than two-thirds of the legislators gave him support--an indication of a strong public dissatisfaction with current state transport and utility services and a clear signal for drastic changes in their provision.
 9 2.15 Governor Alencar inherited a state dominating the urban transport sector, through its ownership of the suburban rail system (Flumitrens), the subway (Metro), the ferry company (CONERJ), two bus companies (CTC and SERVE) and a company which operates terminals and parking garages (CODERTE). In addition, the state owned the dominant water/sanitation and gas companies (CEDAE and CEG, respectively) and a power company (CERJ) with a 21 percent share of the market. Subsidies to the transport companies were massive--estimated in 1995 at US$363 million or 10 percent of state revenues. While operating subsidies to the public utilities were minor, these companies had difficulties expanding coverage due to a shortage of internal financing. Progress of Privatization to Date 2.16 Thus far, progress in the implementation of the state's privatization and concession program has been impressive, due to the strong determination of the Governor's team of senior officials--who were already with Mr. Alencar during his two mandates as mayor of Rio de Janeiro. Another key to this success has been the strong legal support provided by a November 1995, general law to privatize or concession public enterprises and to mandate the establishment of a new regulatory entity for the concession of public services. Without it, the legal challenges that some of the government privatization steps have so far encountered at the state level--particularly to sell the state bank BANERJ--might have been difficult to overcome. 2.17 Specifically, concessioning of Flumitrens' and Metro's transport operations and maintenance services is now in its final phase of preparation. Studies of concessioning models, which were financed by the federal government, have now been completed and reviewed. The government hired a financial advisors' consortium in January 1997, to draft the concession bidding documents for Flumitrens and Metro and promote them with potential investors. The privatization/ concession (and, in one instance, liquidation) of the ferry company CONERJ, of the bus company CTC/SERVE and of the road terminal's operator CODERTE are all underway. Staff reduction programs have already been initiated by the government in all transport companies; further steps will be left to the private groups taking over the companies (or by the state, in case CODERTE is liquidated). Actual concessioning (and/or sale or liquidation) of all state transport services is expected in early 1998. 2.18 The sale of the electricity company CERJ, in November 1996, was a coup for the state government and its aggressive privatization program. A consortium of Chile's Chilectra, Spain's Endesa and Portugal's EDP bought the state's 70.3 percent stake in CERJ for Rs.$605 million, 30 percent above the minimum price the government had established. CERJ is the smaller, and less attractive, of the two electricity companies operating in the state of Rio de Janeiro. While the state capital is served by Light Servicos de Electricidade S.A.--which was sold by the federal government in May 1996, to a consortium led by Electricite de France--CERJ's 4.2 million customers are scattered throughout 57 cities in the state's interior. Nevertheless, the high premium was a result of a sealed-bid auction--a first for the state, which will continue using this type of auction for
 10 the rest of its privatization/concession program--and an aggressive three-continent roadshow. The government is now readying the sale of its gas company, CEG, scheduled in 1997. 2.19 The concession of water and sanitation services and reform of the state company CEDAE is a complex part of the government privatization/concession program because it involves not only the state's municipalities (which are the conceding authorities) but also CEDAE's inefficient but highly unionized labor force. Based on a study financed by the federal government and completed in 1996, the conceptual approach to the concessioning model as well as strategies for the entire water and sanitation sector have now been fully debated by all levels of state government and a final model and strategy agreed upon. On this basis, a financial consortium is preparing the bidding documents for the concession of the metropolitan region's water and sanitation system, except for the concession of Barra da Tijuca and Jacarepagua whose bidding documents have already been issued. Another challenging element of the reform of the state's water and sanitation system is the establishment of cross-sectoral mechanisms to determine acceptable environmental targets for water and sanitation services. The government--in particular the Vice Governor--has been actively working on this aspect of the reform which is essentially a coordination mechanism between environmental and sectoral agencies. 2.20 Finally, to facilitate and regulate public services, in November 1996, the government submitted to the state Assembly a detailed regulatory bill specifying the objectives, responsibilities and organizational arrangements of a single agency with responsibility for all public services within the competence of the state. This Public Services Regulatory Commission will help the state deal with the challenges of tariffs and contractual adaptation. The regulatory bill was submitted in response to the mandate given by the State Assembly in November 1995, to establish a new regulatory framework concurrently with the privatization and concession of public services. Preparation of the law was the object of numerous workshops within the government and of active discussions by the Assembly. The bill was approved on January 15, 1997, and ratified by the Governor on February 13, 1997. The five Directors of the Commission and key personnel will be appointed before the sale of the gas company, based on professional qualifications. They will enjoy protection from arbitrary removal during their fixed (and staggered) terms. As per the January 1997, regulatory law, the appointment of the five Directors must be endorsed by the State Assembly. 2.21 The regulatory law directs the government to make the regulatory commission a small, strong and professional unit that fosters the development of the requisite technical expertise and enjoys a high degree of insulation from day-to-day political pressures. The agency will operate in a transparent manner and be funded from levies on regulated firms (not fines, to avoid conflict of interest). The government has already arranged external assistance to support the regulatory agency's first steps, including training and other start- up costs, until the agency is able to collect sufficient revenues from levies on regulated firms. The agency's detailed responsibilities may vary from sector to sector, and will be defined through concession agreements, possibly augmented by sector-specific decrees. In sectors such as water and gas, it is envisaged that core responsibilities will include
 11 administering tariff adjustment rules and supervising concessionaires' compliance with regulatory norms. Relationships between this agency, state secretaries and responsible environmental and other authorities is being very carefully defined, and appropriate mechanisms put in place to ensure effective coordination. The Commission will supervise concession contracts since, in most sectors, the government intends to rely primarily on concession agreements (which it will grant in accordance with the Federal Concessions Law) as the principal regulatory instrument. Remaining Challenges for the next two years of the Alencar Privatization Program 2.22 Challenges for the New Regulatory Commission. Effectively bringing the regulatory commission to life will be a challenge for the Secretariat of Planning and the Privatization Commission which must overcome the resistance of existing sectoral agencies and government organizations internal to the state. In addition, they must operate within the limits and/or uncertainties imposed by Brazil's federal system, which either limits the state regulatory authority or leaves it vague. Regulation of state public services is further complicated by two main factors. First, tariffs for most public services tend to be politically determined. This can create temptations for the state government to renege on commitments given to private investors by determining tariffs by reference to short-term political considerations. This concern is not a hypothetical one in Rio; in the past, policies of this kind led to the insolvency of private concessionaires operating public services, requiring the government to take over the services in question. Second, the large size and immovable nature of many investments in these public service sectors mean that long-term contracts are often required. This requires the elaboration of a framework that allows regulatory arrangements to be adjusted to meet unforeseen changes while providing appropriate safeguards for private investors. Finally, the long-term nature of private infrastructure arrangements places a premium on particular privatization and related proposals being developed in the context of well-considered market structures and related sector strategies. The government is aware that it will have to strike a balance between short-term goals of revenue maximization and longer-term objectives of developing more competitive and efficient industry structures. However, how it will be done in practice is part of the state's regulatory challenge. 2.23 Challenges for Privatization of Urban Transport Services. A substantial improvement in urban transport services as well as their orderly development and long- term sustainability in the Rio de Janeiro Metropolitan region (RJMR) require resolution of three main issues: i) regulatory and transport planning issues; (ii) subsidies; and (iii) private sector participation in investment and operations. 2.24 On regulations and transport planning, the lack of coordination between the federal, state and municipal levels of government responsible for urban and metropolitan transport--which is particularly critical between the state and the municipal levels--has led to poor tariff and modal integration; lack of prioritization in urban transport investments; and the absence of a common policy on transport pricing and subsidies. Also, the metropolitan region needs to modernize its traffic engineering and control technology to
 12 be able to cope with the present and growing number of road-based vehicles. In particular, it urgently needs to introduce policies aimed at discouraging the rapidly growing use of private vehicles for home-to-work trips, for example, congestion pricing. Congestion is indeed of high public concern. About three quarters of the population of the state of Rio de Janeiro is concentrated in the Rio de Janeiro metropolitan region, which covers only 15 percent of the state's area--9.8 million inhabitants on 546,865 hectares. This population is spread irregularly over 17 individual municipalities which are dominated by the Rio de Janeiro municipality. With 5.7 million inhabitants, the Rio de Janeiro municipality alone has 56 percent of the state population, generates about 85 percent of state income (77 percent of metropolitan region's income) and provides 4,500,000 jobs. Demand for urban transport services is thus highly concentrated in the Rio de Janeiro metropolitan region and, in particular, in the municipality of Rio de Janeiro. Hence, resolving the congestion problem of the metropolitan region and implementing an air quality program for vehicle-based emissions is a challenge that the state of Rio must address in coordination with municipalities. 2.25 In general, regulatory responsibilities for urban transport within a municipality fall under the mayor's jurisdiction while that for metropolitan transport--defined as urban transport involving in most cases more than one municipality--are under the state governor's jurisdiction. In Rio's case, urban transport within the Rio municipality falls under the jurisdiction of the municipal secretariat of transport which mainly oversees buses (all private) and traffic management. Metropolitan transport in the RJMR falls under the jurisdiction of the state secretariat of transport (SECTRAN with 57 employees) which oversees five state-owned enterprises as follows: (i) Flumitrens (a 260-km suburban rail system with 5,396 employees); (ii) Metro (a 23-km subway system with 2,565 employees); (iii) CTC/SERVE (bus with 370 employees); (iv) CONERJ (ferries with 722 employees); and (v) CODERTE (terminals with 521 employees). Since the beginning of project preparation in October 1995, the state has substantially reduced the staff of Flumitrens by about 2,500 employees; Metro by 700 employees; CTC/SERVE by 2,000 employees; CONERJ by 400 employees; and CODERTE 200 employees. 2.26 One of the government's challenges is to clearly define the allocation of responsibilities (and resulting organizational changes) between each of the urban transport agencies, SECTRAN and the state's Public Services Regulatory Commission before granting transport service concessions to the private sector. One particularly important interaction to carefully promote is with the Regional Transport Coordination Commission which the state established in December 1996, to act as an advisory and consensus- enabling body in the following instances: (i) policy coordinator between the federal, state and municipal governments involved in passenger transport; (ii) adviser to the state Public Service Regulatory Commission on regional transport services in general, and in particular, on all urban transport tariff and subsidy policies in the RJMR; (iii) promoter of integrated multimodal fares; and (iv) forum to discuss and prioritize the main investments in Rio's metropolitan region on the basis of economic efficiency and financial sustainability. It will include members of the state transport secretariat, Rio's municipal transport secretariat, other municipalities of Rio's metropolitan region, and operators and users.

There would be bids on the operation and capital (mostly rehabilitation) required for the current system with committed additions. The low bidder for the Net Present Value (NPV) of operating assistance (if needed) plus capital of the current system would be selected. In a separate transaction, the government would ask for bids on operating subsidy (if needed) plus capital contribution from government for the extension, and award this contract to the lowest NPV of capital contribution plus operating assistance. If no bids are received for the extension which fall within the maximum contribution limits, then the project would fail. 2.30 The advantage of option one is that it would certainly get the current Metro system through the concessioning, and it would do so without presenting the risk that the extension will not receive acceptable offers. LESSONS LEARNED FROM PREVIOUS BANK/IDA INVOLVEMENT 3.11 The Bank has extensive experience in the reform of the public sector through structural adjustment loans and sectoral adjustment loans and with subnational development projects in Brazil, Argentina and in other countries. Key lessons (detailed in Annex C) are as follows. First, projects must focus on a few significant reforms that are hard to reverse--such as privatization of public enterprises and banks, and reforms passed via legislation--and can be fully implemented during the mandate of the administration in power. Second, project design and implementation arrangements must be flexible enough to fully achieve targeted reform objectives. Third, reform projects for subnational governments can place very high (sometimes unsustainable) supervision costs on Bank staff. Thus, project implementation should rely as much as possible on the private sector for auditing and procurement review. Finally, the initiative to reform should be entirely the state government's. The Bank can provide financial and technical support, but should never set the basic policy objectives. These lessons have been incorporated into the design of the proposed loan.

PROJECT JUSTIFICATION AND RISKS 4.19 Bank involvement in Rio de Janeiro's state privatization program is prompted by the substantial economic benefits of the program, and its potential as a model for other states. 4.20 Project Benefits. The project's economic benefits derive from its impact on the efficiency of infrastructure services in the state. Deficient infrastructure services are a constraint on the growth of Rio's economy. Unreliable power supply and urban traffic congestion directly impede economic growth, by increasing the costs of doing business in the state. Deteriorating commuter transit systems and the absence of sewerage and drainage in lower-income residential areas have an indirect impact on the state's economy, by reducing labor productivity. The sale of CERJ and CEG and the concessioning of Metro, Flumitrens and CEDAE operations will improve the reliability and increase the coverage of the services provided by these companies. This will significantly increase the productivity of Rio de Janeiro's economy, Brazil's second largest. 4.21 There are also economic benefits to BANERJ's privatization. Sale of the bank will eliminate the economic costs associated with its poor lending decisions. Both the BANERJ sale and the privatization of infrastructure services will also provide fiscal benefits to the state. The sale of BANERJ will eliminate the state's exposure to further losses from the bank's operations. The privatization of the state's urban transport companies will reduce the costs of annual subsidies to these enterprises. 4.22 Rationale for Bank/IDA involvement. Although the state government is proceeding with its privatization program on its own initiative, it has asked for Bank assistance both to strengthen the quality of the program and to finance some of its costs. The Bank's technical advice is more crucial than its financingper se. Privatization and concessions are new to Brazil and the state stands to benefit from the Bank's extensive international experience in this area. Governor Alencar emphasized the importance of Bank support to this program during his discussion with President Wolfensohn on December 5, 1995. From the Bank's perspective, the Rio de Janeiro project is also justified by its wider implications for the country as a whole. The Rio de Janeiro privatization program is the largest and most ambitious in the country. In encompassing the sale of a major bank, establishment of a new regulatory framework for the private provision of public services, privatization of two energy companies, concessions of two large urban transport operations and a partial concession of the state's water and sanitation services, Rio's program demonstrates the scope of what can be accomplished. This lesson will not be lost on other states. In supporting the Rio privatization program, the Bank can thus leverage support for similar reforms throughout the country. 4.23 The proposed project is within the Bank's current Country Assistance Strategy, which calls for support of improvements in the performance of Brazil's public sector. 4.24 Project Risks. The key risk to the project is the sustainability of the regulatory framework. The permanent establishment of a transparent and fair regulatory framework
 40 for the private provision of public services is essential to the project's economic benefits. The framework will take time to become institutionalized, as it represents a radical change in the way the government has traditionally controlled the provision of infrastructure services. It will also require frequent adjustment to remain compatible with the evolving regulatory framework at the federal level. If any federal regulatory development were to cast uncertainty on existing state regulatory arrangements, already-agreed concession contracts may become unstable and require renegotiations costly to the state. 4.25 To mitigate this risk, the state has engaged in extensive discussions with existing public service agencies, legal authorities at the state and federal level and international private providers of such services before drafting its new regulatory law. The new law is now in place, permitting the regulatory commission to be organized and its five-member board to be appointed. In addition, the draft concession contracts for specific enterprises will be drafted in consultation with the federal government to limit regulatory uncertainties. These draft contracts will be included in the bidding documents of the concessions. 4.26 There is also a risk that political opposition will delay some of the program. The state's privatization program continues to frustrate many vested interests--especially unions, whose opposition has been fueled by a fear of job losses. To date, Governor Alencar has been able to maintain wide support from the public and the state assembly for the program. As all the major elements of the program will be achieved during his term of office, the risk of political opposition is considered manageable. 4.27 In addition, there is a risk that the fiscal benefits of privatization will be dissipated by reckless state spending. The approach of the gubernatorial campaign season, combined with the severe shrinkage of the capital investment budget in 1995 and 1996, will increase pressure for spending on ill-conceived capital works. This risk is offset, to some extent, by the difficulty the state will have in raising the financing for such projects. Existing obligations to personnel and debt service will consume most of the net proceeds of privatizations. Provided the federal government enforces the lending restrictions established in the recent debt agreement, the state will have difficulty borrowing. The SRPL project itself will further mitigate this risk, through the public expenditure review included in project conditionality. As described earlier, the Bank will review the government's capital spending program and fiscal performance in 1997, and may suspend disbursement of the 1998 time slice, and the floating water and sanitation time slice, if the state's performance deviates substantially from the targets agreed at negotiations. 4.28 On a smaller scale, there is a risk that municipal opposition will impede the award of water concessions. Unlike power and urban transport services, the state has no authority to award water concessions. This power lies with municipal governments. To mitigate this risk, the state government has worked closely with the mayors as the proposal has evolved. The proposed project itself is designed to ensure that this risk will not impede project implementation as a whole. The water and sanitation reforn is organized as a separate, floating, tranche, rather as part of one of the fixed-time slice disbursements.

 1 ANNEX C LESSONS LEARNED AND PREVIOUS BANK EXPERIENCE IN THE SECTOR 1. The State Reform--Privatization Loan for Rio de Janeiro draws on lessons of experience from a number of Bank projects of similar scope and design in both the Latin America and Caribbean region and Brazil. Because the Bank and other institutions are increasingly supporting regional development, a wider range of experiences in operationalizing and implementing these projects can be used. In addition, the Bank's experience with subnational government projects has evolved rapidly, offering many country- specific insights. Subnational Development Projects 2. Complex project design has often been cited as a key reason for weakening important components of subnational development projects. Aspects such as institutional development and financial management are often neglected in these projects, due to the high demand placed on state implementation and coordination capacities. 3. Experience shows that by identifying and designing key implementation arrangements early in the project preparation process allows for greater flexibility and improved project implementation. In the case of the Minas Gerais Municipal Management and Environmental Infrastructure Project (Ln. 3639-BR), the Terms of Reference to be used and implementation arrangements were discussed during the project's preparation phase. This helped shape the dialogue between the Bank and the state, and, moreover clarified and better defined project objectives and scope for both parties. Increased borrower involvement during these stages also has the benefit of giving governments greater project ownership. 4. In its 1992 review of urban and municipal projects in Brazil, OED found that many projects did not pay enough attention to the external environment in which they would be implemented. Tailoring project implementation periods to political mandates is particularly important in the case of Brazil, as it helps to capture government support for a project. As an alternative, projects that have a flexible project design can easily accommodate shifting political priorities. Additionally, any pilot programs need to be quickly implemented to capitalize on a climate of favorable political and community support. Project Sector Reforms in Brazil 5. One of the most relevant projects with respect to design and scope of the Rio SRPL is the Brazil Public Sector Management Project (Ln. 2721-BR). This project sought to develop planning and management capacity on the federal level in the areas of sector and project analysis, multi-year investment planning, and program monitoring. Another major component of the project was an integrated budget information and control system. One key
 2 lesson of experience is that project design should not be overly ambitious since the loan size, the project's operational complexity, and the number of project components can ultimately burden both the Borrower and the Bank during implementation and supervision. Privatization of Public Enterprises in Argentina 6. Under the Public Enterprise Reform Project in Argentina (Ln. 3291-AR), the following lessons were learned. The initiative to privatize was entirely the government's. The Bank was vital in providing financial and technical support, but never set the basic policy objective. 7. The Bank prudently kept a low profile; in spite of a ubiquitous Bank presence, privatization never became a "World Bank Program" in the eyes of political or public opinion. 8. A large amount of relevant sector work had been done by the Bank before there was any indication that a privatization program might be possible. Since at the time, the chances for any lending resulting from this work were quite low, it may well be thought of as a high- risk gamble. The gamble paid off, but without this technical work, it would have been difficult for the new government to seize the moment and push ahead with privatization when a pervasive sense of national crisis gave it the needed political support. 9. Implementation was greatly enhanced by a highly effective Project Unit. The fact that the head of the Unit participated, from the beginning, in loan discussions and formal negotiations, enabled the Unit to play a constructive role during implementation. 10. The Bank's imaginative use of adjustment lending, in allowing visible application of counterpart proceeds to finance severance payments, was decisive in making railroad privatization feasible. But its justification hinged on two circumstances: monitoring to prevent rehiring or replacement and, even more important, imminent privatization, after which the pressures to overstaff would, presumably, largely disappear. Operational Aspects 11. Disbursement has been a traditional problem in Brazil due to the long-standing incompatibility between Brazil's federal procurement law and Bank guidelines. Disbursement lags also persisted due to federal regulation that mandated that all special accounts be held in the central bank. In 1993, federal legislation was enacted to allow public entities to hold projects accounts in institutions outside the central bank. Concrete steps have also been taken to improve procurement procedures thorough the issuing of Standard Bidding Documents for National Competitive Bidding (NCB) that were agreed upon by the Federal Government and the Bank.
