 1 ANNEX D MODERNIZATION OF ENVIRONMENTAL MANAGEMENT IN THE STATE OF RIO DE JANEIRO 1. BACKGROUND A. Rio and the Environment 1. The state of Rio de Janeiro suffers from a number of very serious pollution problems that have significant costs for the health of the population and for the ability of the state to attract tourism and industry: (a) For many, Guanabara Bay as seen from the Sugar Loaf is the symbol of Rio. Today, however, the Bay is badly polluted and smelly, and its western parts are effectively dead. (b) Particulate air pollution in the northern part of Rio Municipality and the Baixada Fluminense is serious enough to causes health damage including premature mortality. (c) Sepetiba Bay, to the west of the Rio de Janeiro Metropolitan Area (RJMA), is an area of rapid economic development. However, current emissions already exceed the absorptive capacity of the ecologically sensitive bay. (d) The risk of accidental industrial spills on the Rio Paraiba do Sul constitutes a serious threat to the safety of the drinking water supply of most of the state's population. (e) Pollution of ocean beaches and lakes significantly reduces the value of the state's touristic attractions. 2. As a result of poor political support under previous administrations and serious staffing and salary problems in the environmental agencies, the current environmental management system is in disarray and unable to cope effectively with the serious pollution problems. Moreover, bureaucratic environmental licensing requirements, unpredictable regulations and a lack of reliable environmental information and planning impose significant costs on businesses without achieving commensurate environmental gains. 3. On the one hand, the cost of excessive pollution and the cost of poor environmental management have become an important obstacle to the economic development of the state. On the other hand, continued economic and industrial development will aggravate the environmental situation unless drastic measures are taken to improve the state's environmental management system. 4. Improving environmental management is not a financial but a management problem. If the resources of public sector budgets were applied to strategic priorities, and if cost- effective instruments were used to reduce pollution from industry and the water and sanitation sector, the financing requirements for public administration, industry and water and sanitation companies will definitely be affordable.
 2 5. Since September 1995, the state government has been working closely with a World Bank team on developing a strategy for improving environmental management'. This work has used systematic economic, cross-sectoral analysis and the limited available information to develop cost-effective strategies for tackling priority problems and outlining an overall environmental management strategy. Among the large number of recommendations resulting from that work, there are five critical actions which are necessary conditions for any significant progress and all have a direct impact on the proposed SRPL, especially on the water and sanitation reforms envisaged under the project: (a) the integration of agreed wastewater treatment targets in the ongoing process to restructure the water and sanitation sector, (b) a process for agreeing on environmental targets over time for the most important waterbasins and airsheds of the state through a State Environmental Action Plan; (c) introduction of more cost-effective pollution management through a water basin committee system and effluent discharge fees; (d) steps to ensure that a small number of technical staff in the pollution enforcement agency is well equipped, effectively managed and sufficiently well paid to implement a strategic enforcement program for the most important industrial polluters and to administer a streamlined licensing process with the necessary flexibility and speed; and (e) upgrading of the environmental monitoring and information systems to allow systematic ambient monitoring. B. Policies 6. Rio's environmental regulations cover the most important polluting activities. However, implementation and enforcement are widely lacking. The combination of federal, state and local environmental regulations has created a highly complex system of requirements that is confusing for polluters and difficult to enforce. Moreover, the range of policy instruments used for pollution management is still very limited. 7. The objectives of environmental policy are formally defined in ambient environmental standards. The federal government has established water and air quality standards through resolutions of the National Environment Council (CONAMA). For example, CONAMA Resolution 20/1986 determines ambient standards for nine water use classes for the main water pollutants. At the national level there are the PROAGUA national water quality program and the PRONAR national air quality control program, which include ambient monitoring, administration of emission licenses, and a national emissions inventory. The implementation of most policies is the responsibility of the state. 8. The two main instruments for industrial pollution management are zoning and licensing. Zoning is unevenly used by local, state and federal governments. State zoning regulations were originally linked to prevailing ambient pollution levels but have not been revised to reflect changing environmental conditions. The licensing system requires a valid license for every potentially polluting enterprise (based on the Rio de Janeiro State Pollution Further details can be obtained from the Report No 15488-BR "Brazil: Managing Environmental Pollution in the State of Rio de Janeiro" on which this Annex is based.
 3 Activities Licensing System, Decree 1,633/1977). The firms' licensing applications contain information on technical parameters and emissions based on which the State Environment Control Council (CECA) grants or refuses the license, which is renewable every five years. For activities with a large polluting potential, the evaluation of an Environmental Impact Assessment (EIA) is part of the licensing process. According to state law 13 56/1988 on EIA, the State Pollution Control Agency (FEEMA) is involved in defining the technical specification for the EIA, which is then submitted to CECA for approval. 9. Environmental fines are based on a system that considers levels of toxicity, frequency of infraction and the size/volume of effluent. While this system is operating, fines have been too low and enforcement efforts too sporadic to induce systematic compliance with environmental regulations. In 1991, a State law was passed which requires environmental audits in all enterprises. The corresponding regulation was decreed in 1995. So far there is no experience with the implementation of this instrument. Industrial effluents entering the sewerage system are subject to a load-based charge that is levied by the state water company (CEDAE) for the main pollutants. A share of these charges is supposed to be passed on to the State Environment Agency (FEEMA). C. Institutional Structure 10. Environmental management in Rio State is the responsibility of the State Secretary of the Environment (SEMA). The Secretary has only a small staff and oversees the work of four State Environment Agencies: (a) The State Pollution Control Agency (FEEMA) employs about 1,000 staff (250 with university degrees) and is in charge of licensing, monitoring and enforcement of environmental regulation. FEEMA has also an active role in preparing environmental norms for SEMA, and has also responsibility for vehicle emission controls. (b) The Water Resource Management Agency (SERLA) has about 500 staff (80 professionals). A large part of staff and budget are devoted to the execution of water resource related works and dredging operations. (c) The forest agency (IDF) has 245 employees (of which 66 are professionals and 54 technicians). (d) The Mineral Resource Agency (DRM) has a staff of 122. 11. Other important organs of environmental policy are the State Commission for Environmental Control (CECA) which includes representatives of most state secretaries and has one chamber for the approval of regulations and another chamber for the approval of enforcement acts by the environmental agencies. The State Environment Council (CONEMA) consists of representatives of Government and civil society and oversees environmental policy in the state. CECA and FEEMA were created in 1975. The other entities were later integrated into the environmental management system. 2. MAIN POLICY ISSUES AND PROPOSED REFORMS 12. Since its foundation, 20 years ago, FEEMA has served as a model agency for the entire country regarding environmental management, technical expertise and the legal
 4 framework it had developed. However, over the last eight years, FEEMA has undergone drastic decline caused by poor political support, very limited budgets, and weak strategic direction. As a result of this decline, FEEMA has become trapped in a cycle of decline of limited effectiveness and limited resources and authorities. FEEMA is no longer effective in fulfilling some of its basic functions such as systematic monitoring of emissions and ambient quality as well as spot-checks and site visits with polluters. FEEMA's reduced monitoring and enforcement activities have reduced its credibility with polluters and the public, making it more difficult to assert the authority required to meet FEEMA's responsibilities. In turn, as a less effective agency, FEEMA has problems in justifying its budgets and asserting its responsibilities toward other agencies. 13. The environmental agencies have in recent years not been substantially involved in important decision processes with significant environmental impacts. The result of this exclusion is that environmental concerns are often not considered from the beginning in important investment projects, but encountered as a constraint after the planning process is completed. This procedure has led to polarization and stigmatization of environmental agencies as obstacles to effective execution of investment projects. 14. The state government has recognized the serious problems of its environmental management system and decided to make improved environmental management a priority area. Actions to be taken include steps toward a modernization of the sector within its overall program of state reform. The state government has embarked on an ambitious reform program that includes the following three components, discussed in detail in subsequent sections: (a) the establishment of accountability of environmental agencies through transparent target setting, explicit performance targets, and a restructuring of environmental agencies focusing on: (i) clarifying the agencies' responsibilities; and (ii) decentralizing many tasks to local Governments or self-administrating systems, such as water basin agencies, and the private sector, (b) a modernization of the instruments of environmental management toward the increased use of economic instruments; and (c) the integration of environmental objectives into the restructuring and privatization of state enterprises under the state reform program. 3. ACCOUNTABILITY IN ENVIRONMENTAL MANAGEMENT A. Current Problems 15. The key factor that has led to the decline of environmental management in the state was the lack of political support and accountability for the performance of the agencies. The effectiveness of the environmental institutions was reduced by withdrawing necessary funding, letting salaries slip to non-competitive levels and denying the agencies the political backing it needed when it wanted to enforce environmental regulations. 16. From this lack of political support, a management system without clear accountability has evolved. Environmental targets were set independently of the
 5 authorizations of budgets and instruments for achieving these targets. As a result, the environmental agencies do not have the power to achieve the targets and thus cannot not be held accountable for these targets. For example, the setting of wastewater treatment targets for sanitation companies without coordination with environmental agencies, means that the agencies do not have the means of achieving overall water quality targets. Gaps and overlaps in the responsibility of different environmental agencies further undermine accountability. B. State Environmental Action Plan and Performance Targets 17. Accountability requires the establishment of clear targets for environmental management expressed in ambient quality parameters to be attained for specific locations over a specified period of time. Since environmental problems are inherently cross-sectoral in nature, targets need to be set in a high-level cross-sectoral coordination process. Realistic targets will be set for each sink (airshed or water basin), taking both damages and abatement costs into account. The setting of targets and the implementation of pollution management policies will be undertaken with as much transparency and participation by polluters and affected communities as possible. The cross-sectoral participatory process to develop explicit environmental targets will begin in early 1997. A State Environmental Action Plan is expected to be approved by the state government in early 1998. 18. Explicit performance targets for the environmental agencies will be derived from the State Environmental Action Plan. In return, the agencies will be receiving the staffing flexibility, budget resources and authorities for the use of specific instruments needed for the attainment of the targets. This authorization needs to be backed by top-level policy makers giving the environmental agencies the actual power to enforce the authorized instruments. The agencies will produce an annual performance report which provides a clear, simple accounting of environmental quality, emissions sources, and agency operations in pursuit of agreed-upon objectives. C. Agency Restructuring 19. SEMA is currently preparing a comprehensive restructuring and modernization plan aimed at eliminating overlaps and gaps in the responsibility of environmental agencies. The state agencies will focus on the core functions, including enforcement and supervisory activities, and redirect their activities to "second-tier" functions while decentralizing actual policy implementation to: (a) the private sector where services -- such as ambient monitoring -- can be contracted out; (b) municipalities where pollution activities have only local scope; and (c) self-organizing bodies such as water basin agencies. The environmental agencies will focus on the setting of policies and the supervision of actual policy implementation. The government aims to have implemented the first phase of the restructuring plan (including performance targets for the new agencies) by mid-1997.
 6 4. STAFFING AND BUDGETING PROBLEMS A. Current Problems 20. The environmental agencies are paralyzed by an excessive number of poorly paid and unmotivated staff as well as serious budget rigidities. In many cases, the agencies do not have the right staff-skill mix for implementing a modem regulatory approach to environmental management. Moreover, the pay for professional staff is not competitive, as well as unequal and unresponsive to performance. Inflexible budget procedures and lack of timely access to budgeted resources are serious constraints limiting the availability of non- staff resources and reducing the effective utilization of staff. 21. With the exception of DRM, the environmental agencies are parastatal institutions (funda,ces). However, most of the rigidities of the government employment system still apply to these organizations. FEEMA has two types of employees: "celetistas" under federal law, and "estatuarios" under state law. Both enjoy quasi lifetime employment guarantee. The constitutional employment guarantee reduces staffing flexibility and makes it almost impossible to dismiss unproductive or obsolete staff and replace them with staff that could contribute new skills. Lifetime employment and declining budgets have made new hiring almost impossible. Over the last 15 years, no formal competition for the hiring of new staff has taken place. 22. In FEEMA, real average monthly salaries for professional staff have eroded from the equivalent of nearly Rs.$3,000 in the mid-1980s to Rs.$900 at present. The salaries for professionals are not competitive with salaries in the private sector or state enterprises, such as CEDAE. Salaries do not differ by experience or performance, and within the regular salary system there are no built-in merit incentives. 23. As the result of low salaries, lack of performance incentives and protection from job loss, absenteeism is high and work motivation is minimal. Out of FEEMA's staff of 977, 149 are lent to other agencies or retired (but still paid for by FEEMA). Of the active staff of 828, at least 30% do not report to work regularly and an additional 30% of full time staff only work part-time. Ultimately, the number of effective full-time staff is probably less than 200. In many cases, work productivity is minimal. 24. On the one hand, the staffing system leaves agency management very little flexibility to hire or fire personnel. On the other hand, the budget system reduces the agency's ability to effectively employ current staff. The overall share of FEEMA's budget has declined from 1.5% of the state budget in the mid eighties to 0.5% in 1995. Discretionary budgets for non- staff operations expenses are low and -- even if they were sufficient -- not actually accessible. Funds often do not become available until late into the fiscal year. B. Suggested Reforms 25. Improvements in environmental management will depend on substantially improved basic working conditions of the agencies and sufficiently flexible staffing levels. The new system will require the setting of priorities and supervision of decentralized activities that depends on highly qualified staff in the agencies that can only be attracted or retained at competitive salary levels. Therefore, salary levels for remaining and new professional staff
 7 will have to be raised significantly. Also, new agencies will have a ratio between professional staff and technicians and support staff much higher than in the present agencies. A simple numerical example can show the compatibility of adequate salaries for a small number of key professionals with budget reductions. 26. Pending federal reforms would allow involuntary staff reductions, thus also allowing the hiring of staff to meet the changed requirements of the agencies. If involuntary staff reductions are not legally possible, excess staff would be formally removed from their positions and offices (in the case of absent staff this implies little change but a reorganization of work that acknowledges the already effectively much smaller size of the organizations). 27. Total sector budgets appear adequate if the proposed staffing changes can be implemented. Key is the availability of sufficient budget for discretionary operating expenses and management of these resources by agencies within performance contracts. Increased cost recovery for some services, such as licenses, can contribute toward the related expenses but is unlikely to reach a significant share of total budgets. The use of environmental fines and emission charges to support the recurrent costs of the agencies will also be considered. 28. The action plan for staff and budget restructuring which the government may consider implementing by early 1998, consists of the following elements: (a) increased flexibility in the hiring and firing of staff for the agencies; (b) an overall reduction of staff with an introduction of more competitive salaries for qualified new and remaining staff, (c) increased pay equity for equal positions and introduction of merit-based salary components; (d) assurance of sufficient discretionary operations budgets for the agencies, together with more flexibility and timely availability of these resources. 5. POLLUTION MANAGEMENT INSTRUMENTS A. Current Problems 29. Current environmental management instruments are largely based on a command- and-control approach and a rather inflexible bureaucratic mentality. The licensing process is not focused on environmental impact but on micro-management of detailed engineering aspects of individual plants. Moreover, there is no effective link that ties environmental policies to the ambient environmental conditions in specific locations. Cross-sectoral planning and coordination of environmental policy is lacking. Economic thinking and the desire to develop flexible and cost-effective solutions to pollution problems is not yet widespread. For example, the lack of integration between effluent controls from industry and the sanitation sector, and between air emissions from industry and transport, had led to pollution reduction measures that are not always cost-effective. There has been very little cooperation between environmental agencies and the industry and other polluters, even though experience elsewhere suggest that such cooperation is critical for effective pollution reduction.
 8 B. Proposed Reforms 30. The thorough modernization of environmental management instruments will focus on a reorientation of administrative regulation that is based on detailed involvement of agency staff in plant engineering to an output-oriented economic approach that focuses on key environmental impact parameters. Economic instruments, such as effluent charges and tradable emission permits, will replace, or amend, step by step existing administrative instruments such as emission standards and complex licensing procedures. Clear and consistently-applied regulations will permit flexible responses by polluters while providing strong financial incentives to abate critical pollutants. A cost-effective pollution management strategy will be applied consistently across sectors, requiring the integration of air pollution control in transport, industry, and garbage burning, and water pollution control in industry, households, and the water and sanitation sector. 31. Given the current weaknesses of the environmental management system, a strategic focus on key problems is absolutely critical. Many low-cost pollution abatement options are available in specific cases. Obviously, policies should focus on these inexpensive solutions first. At least in the short and medium term, this means focusing on critical sinks and critical pollutants and focusing principally on large pollution sources while at the same time directing sufficient attention to other polluters to encourage compliance at reasonable levels and establishing the general rules of the game, which in the long term will be enforced for all polluters. 32. Once priority areas have been determined, policies need to be strongly and consistently enforced. The agencies have lost credibility with polluters due to declining enforcement activity. This credibility needs to be rebuilt in order to make the agencies an effective counterpart for often powerful polluters. To build this credibility, consistent and strong enforcement of a few selected priority areas is more effective than a large number of impressive but unenforced or unenforceable policies. 33. Efficient pollution management is based on transparent rules and principles that apply across the state but also on flexibility in appropriately applying these rules to specific pollution problems. The natural focus of environmental management is on regions defined by natural water basins and airsheds (sinks). Decentralized management systems within an overall policy framework are most effective in implementing this approach. For example, municipalities, water basin agencies, and airshed committees will be authorized by the environmental agencies to apply environmental policy instruments to pollution problems within their domain. This approach implies the delegation of certain regulatory functions under the overall supervision of the environmental agencies. 34. The key reform of environmental management instruments consists of the introduction of a comprehensive system of water basin agencies. Plans for the introduction of this system are well advanced, and a draft law will be presented to the legislature during 1997. The draft law provides for the application of effluent discharge fees within the water basin management systems. The draft law will be revised to incorporate the right of the state to impose a discharge effluent fee if a water basin agency has not been formed or has not produced an acceptable pollution management plan within a specified time period. This charge mechanism will create efficient economic incentives for pollution reduction and
 9 prevent a perverse incentive against the formation of water basin agencies if the discharge fee were only levied within such systems. The discharge fee will be phased in gradually over a period of several years. Once the revised water resource management law, which the government intends to submit to the state assembly this year, has been passed, formation of key water basin committees will be encouraged and the effluent discharge fee would be phased in. 35. The agencies will be reoriented toward a more cooperative approach vis-A-vis polluters. While their ultimate enforcement power cannot be questioned, the agencies will focus on negotiations, voluntary compliance agreements and assistance for enterprises and other polluters in attaining environmental targets. Within the public sector, environmental agencies will actively participate in the design of major new projects, allowing them to contribute constructively. The role of the agencies will change from a pure environmental police function to a service provider function, in particular through the provision of environmental information. 6. STATE ENTERPRISE RESTRUCTURING 36. The State Environment Secretariat SEMA is actively involved in all aspects of the state privatization program, in particular through an analysis of the potential environmental effects of the program and the design of measures to remedy possible negative impacts. As an example, environmental audits were undertaken prior to the privatization of the energy companies, CERJ and CEG. Because of its major contribution to pollution problems in the state, the restructuring of the water and sanitation sector deserves more detailed analysis from an environmental perspective. The environmental implications of the reform components in the transport sector are more limited. However, a brief analysis is provided in a subsequent section. A. Water and Sanitation Sector (1) Wastewater Treatment 37. The water and sanitation sector is, for most conventional pollutants, the main source of water pollution in the state. Up to the present, there is very little sewage treatment, and raw sewage from collection systems and uncollected runoff directly enter the waterbodies. The ongoing IDB/OECF-financed Guanabara Bay Basic Sanitation Project includes additional sewage treatment investments. However, with the concurrent expansion of sewage collection networks there is little change in the total discharge of effluent from the sector. 38. One of the reasons for considering increased private sector participation in the water and sanitation sector is the need to generate the financing needed to expand basic sanitation services and associated wastewater treatment. The planned reforms have, thus, a significant positive environmental effect, and if properly designed, can contribute greatly to improved environmental management in the state. Since the environmental targets to be set for the new utilities will be a critical factor in determining both the economic feasibility and the environmental consequences of restructuring, careful coordination of the environmental aspects of the water and sanitation sector restructuring is of great importance.
 10 39. Fundamental decisions about what level of wastewater collection and disposal services should be provided and how this should be financed must be made in the near future. These are essentially environmental decisions that are linked with strategic choices about future levels of environmental quality in the main river basins of the state. It is of critical importance that a consistent set of environmental targets and obligations for the restructured utilities be developed early in the process through a coordinated mechanism between the water and sanitation sector, on the one hand, and the environment sector, on the other hand. In this way, the potential implications of alternative options for investment requirements, tariffs, and environmental quality can be assessed before taking the final political decisions. 40. Once wastewater treatment targets have been agreed by the government, they will have to be incorporated in the sector restructuring as an obligation of the concessionaire and in the applicable environmental license. Once the sector has been restructured, there is no reason to treat water and sanitation companies differently from other large point pollution sources. Therefore, the concession contract should provide for a transition from a rigid regime with fixed targets, for instance in the first few years of the contract, to the general environmental management regime. In the latter regime, water and sanitation companies will be represented as users within the water basin management structure, and will be subject to the normal licensing, monitoring, and inspection requirements applied to other companies. After a transitional period, they will also be required to pay effluent discharge fees either to the state or to the relevant water basin agency. Failure to meet the terms of their discharge permits will expose them to the imposition of fines and/or other penalties. 41. There is a need to establish an effective coordination mechanism between the economic and the environmental regulation of the concessions. The government has hired a consultant to develop a mechanism for coordinating the economic and environmental regulation of water and sewage operators. Specific wastewater treatment targets and the mechanism for coordinating economic and environmental regulation will be reflected in the concession contracts and the applicable environmental licenses. (2) Drinking Water Quality 42. Currently, FEEMA is contracted by CEDAE to undertakes regular analyses of drinking water quality in the CEDAE network. Monthly samples from about 1,000 monitoring points are analyzed for fecal coliform and residual chlorine. The results are submitted to the Secretary of Health, which has responsibility for supervising drinking water. Revised drinking water standards from 1991 are based on WHO guidelines and cover a large number of potential pollutants. Since FEEMA does not have the capacity to undertake monitoring according to the 1991 standards, CEDAE plans to contract private laboratories for regular analysis of water samples for compliance with the new standards. The private laboratories will have to be certified by FEEMA. The requirement to comply with 1991 standards and submit water quality analysis from a certified laboratory to the Secretary of Health will also apply to any future private sector operator. 43. The Rio Paraiba do Sul is the primary source of drinking water for the Rio de Janeiro metropolitan area. A total of 160 m3/s is transferred from the Rio Paraiba do Sul to the Guandu river basin via the Light-Guandu system with its Santa Cecilia pumping station
 11 downstream from Volta Redonda. Most of this transfer is used to generate electricity but 47 m3/s is abstracted from the Guandu by CEDAE's main water treatment plant. 44. Current levels of bacteriological contamination and organic material in the Paraiba do Sul do not pose any significant threat to drinking water supplies for Rio de Janeiro or other towns and cities in the Rio Paraiba do Sul basin since, at worst, they imply slight additional costs of treatment. Even though water quality levels for heavy metals and toxic organic chemicals are within threshold levels set for drinking water supplies, upstream discharges will be reduced wherever this can be achieved at reasonable cost. The five-year compliance agreement between FEEMA and CSN foresees a reduction of emissions of benzo-pyrene and other hydrocarbons from the CSN plant. FEEMA's enforcement will focus on compliance with this agreement. 45. The nature and extent of potential risks associated with the eutrophication of the Funil Reservoir, upstream on the Rio Paraiba do Sul, cannot be assessed with current data. It is asserted that the level of algae in the intake for the water treatment plant has been rising and may reach unacceptable levels in the future. More detailed technical analysis is required before any conclusions about the priority to be attached to this problem can be drawn. 46. Spills and other accidental discharges of hazardous pollutants from industrial plants upstream of the pumping station have occurred and will occur in the future. It seems that these emergencies are dealt with on an ad-hoc basis. This is not satisfactory. Transit times down the river are short so that immediate action may be required if the pumping station had to be shut down in order to allow the spill to pass on down the river. Even if pollutants discharged in an accident get into the Guandu system, there are a variety of options including temporary closure of the Guandu water intake and reliance on other water sources. At the moment it seems that insufficient attention has been paid to developing a clear emergency response system, together with measures designed to ensure that the water abstraction arrangements have sufficient flexibility to mitigate the hazards posed by a serious accident. 47. An emergency response system to deal in a graduated manner with the risks posed by accidental spills from chemical and other plants along the river must be developed as quickly as possible. A critical aspect will be to ensure that there are clear mechanisms for assessing the hazards posed by spills and for reporting all necessary information to those who have to take action as well as to the relevant regulatory authorities. There should be provision for severe penalties to be imposed on any company that fails to report a potentially hazardous spill promptly. The development of an emergency response system will be linked to the restructuning of the water and sanitation sector. If it is decided that the Guandu treatment plant were to be privatized, the concession contract will specify clear performance targets for: (a) managing emergencies resulting from accidental spills as well as other causes, and (b) investing, as appropriate, in measures -- such as additional separate storage capacity and water intakes -- designed to increase the flexibility of the system in the face of such emergencies. (3) Environmental Audits 48. All facilities to be privatized will be subject to an environmental audit for compliance with applicable regulations, which will determine measures required before the concessioning
 12 and obligations for the concessionaire to be included in the concession contract. Depending on which facilities will eventually be privatized, audits would include the water intake and the Guandu treatment plant including the need for an emergency response system, water quality and sampling methods, wastewater discharges, and disposal of solid waste from wastewater treatment plants. B. Transport Sector 49. The effect of transport sector policies on air pollution cannot be systematically assessed at present, due to the lack of basic data on vehicle emissions, ambient quality and control costs. However, very preliminary work suggests that the contribution of the transport sector to ambient concentration of total suspended particulates, the main problem in the Rio de Janeiro Metropolitan Area, is less than 20%. However, the contribution to fine particulates, which are of special concern because of their health effect, will be larger. Transport emissions also have a much larger contribution to ground-level ozone concentration. However, at this time, there is no data are available to verify the existence of a significant ground-level ozone problem in Rio de Janeiro. 50. PROCONVE (Programa de Controle da Polui,co do Ar por Veiculos Automotores) is the national program for control of vehicle emissions. National vehicle standards for new vehicles have been determined by CONAMA Resolution 18 of May 6, 1986, with a schedule of tightening emission standards and a series of subsequent regulations for gasoline and alcohol-powered vehicles. CONAMA Resolution 10 of September 14, 1989 establishes standards for diesel vehicles. CONAMA Resolution No. 7 of August 31, 1993 sets emission standards for vehicle in use. 51. Since 1988, FEEMA has undertaken spot checks of heavy diesel vehicles for black smoke and issued fines (in theory, US$1,300 per violation) to vehicles failing the test. The spot-check program has been complemented by a call-in line to FEEMA for the denunciation of smoke-belching vehicles. The systematic program of spot-checks of heavy duty vehicles was abandoned in the early 1990s in favor of occasional measuring campaigns. During a campaign in 1993-94, 1,324 diesel vehicles were inspected out of which 64% were fined for violations. Currently, there is no program of periodic vehicle inspection and maintenance. However such program is planned under a draft law currently awaiting approval in the State Legislature. 52. The gasoline (gasohol) typically sold in Rio contains 22% alcohol. In addition, some vehicles use pure alcohol as fuel. Following a program by the municipality to encourage the use of CNG as a cleaner fuel, there are currently about 2,000 taxis and 200 urban buses operating on CNG. Lead has been phased out from gasoline since 1991. The average sulfur content of diesel is 0.7% country-wide and 0.5% in major metropolitan areas including Rio. 53. Since the information base on which to build more effective monitoring of vehicle emission controls is extremely weak, the government will undertake a comprehensive study of air pollution problems in the RJMA which will determine the contribution of the transport sector to air pollution problems. In particular, this study will assess the extent of air pollution with pollutants not currently monitored (in particular PM- 10 and ozone), compile a detailed emission inventory, undertake preliminary dispersion and photochemical oxidant
 13 formation, analyze control options and propose a cost-effective air quality control strategy. Based on the study, a transport sector emission strategy will be developed by early 1998. 54. The state reform program includes the sale of a very small share of the city's total bus fleet. All buses to be sold will be required to have a certificate of compliance with environmental regulations prior to and at the point of sale. For CONERJ's ferryboats, Flumitrens, and Metr6 facilities, an environmental audit will be carried out prior to inviting the concession bids. The sale or concessioning agreements will include the necessary environmental and safety safeguards.

doc.abstracts: The Rio de Janeiro State Reform-Privatization Project's main objective is to support the state's privatization and concession program, and increase efficiency in the delivery of urban transport and utility services. During preparation, the aim has been to improve the quality of the design of the state's privatization and concession program and assist in its initial phase of implementation. The project itself will ensure that implementation is completed as planned. The components of the project are the following: 1) privatization of BANERJ SA and of BANERJ Insurance SA as well as liquidation of Banco do Estado do Rio de Janeiro SA and of its pension fund; 2) establishment of a new regulatory framework for the private provision of public services; 3) concession of the services of Rio's main urban transport agencies and divestiture of their non-operational assets; 4) privatization of the energy companies--the electricity company CERJ and the gas company CEG; 5) concession of water and sanitation services; and 6) satisfactory review of the 1997 fiscal performance.
